   357
   358### Validation Categories
   359
   360#### Architecture Compliance
   361- **Agent placement**: Correct subdirectory based on role
   362- **Naming conventions**: kebab-case filenames matching agent names
   363- **Hierarchy adherence**: Proper orchestrator  specialist  analyzer structure
   364
   365#### Tool Security
   366- **Permission boundaries**: Agents only have necessary tools
   367- **Security isolation**: Read-only agents cannot modify files
   368- **Tool count limits**: 3-7 tools per agent for cognitive load optimization
   369
   370#### Model Allocation
   371- **Complexity matching**: Model matches cognitive load requirements
   372- **Cost optimization**: No over-allocation of expensive models
   373- **Consistency**: Similar agents use similar models
   374
   375#### Chain Integration
   376- **Security chains**: Mandatory security validation configured
   377- **Handoff patterns**: Proper agent-to-agent coordination
   378- **Error handling**: Fallback mechanisms defined
   379
   380### Common Compliance Issues
   381
   382```bash
   383 ISSUE: Agent has 12 tools (exceeds cognitive load limit of 7)
   384 FIX: Reduce to core tools or split into multiple specialized agents
   385
   386 ISSUE: Read-only agent has Write tool access
   387 FIX: Remove Write tools, change to write_limited security level
   388
   389 ISSUE: Simple task agent using opus model
   390 FIX: Change to sonnet or haiku based on cognitive complexity
   391
   392 ISSUE: Missing security chain integration
   393 FIX: Add mandatory security validation handoff
   394```
   395
   396## Best Practices
   397
   398### Agent Selection Guidelines
   399
   4001. **Complex multi-step tasks**  Use workflow-orchestrator
   4012. **Security-critical code**  Mandatory security chain (non-negotiable)
   4023. **Domain-specific work**  Use appropriate specialist
   4034. **Analysis-only tasks**  Use read-only analyzers
   4045. **Simple formatting**  Use haiku-model agents
   405
   406### Orchestration Guidelines
   407
   4081. **Plan workflows** with TodoWrite before agent delegation
   4092. **Respect tool boundaries** - never override security restrictions
   4103. **Chain mandatory validations** for security-critical operations
   4114. **Optimize model allocation** based on actual cognitive complexity
   4125. **Document decisions** in agent coordination workflows
   413
   414### Error Handling
   415
   4161. **Agent failures**  Retry with alternative agent or escalate model
   4172. **Security violations**  Immediately involve security-orchestrator
   4183. **Tool permission errors**  Check .claude/agents/config/tool-permissions.yaml
   4194. **Chain interruptions**  Resume from last successful checkpoint
   420
   421This reference provides complete documentation for understanding, using, and extending the hierarchical multi-agent system in CC-Boilerplate.

# Agent System Reference

## Table of Contents

- [System Overview](#system-overview)
- [Agent Hierarchy](#agent-hierarchy)
- [Orchestration Patterns](#orchestration-patterns)
- [Tool Permissions](#tool-permissions)
- [Model Allocation](#model-allocation)
- [Chain Configuration](#chain-configuration)
- [Compliance Validation](#compliance-validation)

## System Overview

The CC-Boilerplate implements a **Hierarchical Multi-Agent Architecture** (ADR-007) with autonomous orchestration, security-first tool allocation, and cognitive load-based model assignment.

### Core Principles

```
 **HIERARCHICAL STRUCTURE** - Orchestrators coordinate specialists
 **SECURITY BOUNDARIES** - Role-based tool restrictions enforced
 **COGNITIVE OPTIMIZATION** - Model allocation matches task complexity
 **MANDATORY CHAINS** - Security validation enforced automatically
 **AUTONOMOUS SELECTION** - Agents selected by task description matching
```

### Architecture Components

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User Request] --> B{Complexity Assessment}
    B -->|Complex Multi-Step| C[workflow-orchestrator]
    B -->|Security-Critical| D[security-orchestrator]
    B -->|Domain-Specific| E[Specialized Agents]

    C --> F[Agent Chain Execution]
    D --> G[Security Validation Chain]
    E --> H[Direct Task Execution]

    F --> I[Quality Assurance]
    G --> I
    H --> I

    I --> J[Result Integration]
```

## Agent Hierarchy

### Primary Orchestrators (Opus Model)

#### workflow-orchestrator
- **Purpose**: Complex multi-step coordination and feature implementation
- **Use When**: Tasks requiring 3+ agents, cross-domain coordination
- **Tools**: Task, TodoWrite, Read
- **Model**: opus (high cognitive load for strategic planning)

#### security-orchestrator
- **Purpose**: Security validation chain coordination
- **Use When**: ANY security-critical code modifications
- **Tools**: Task, Read
- **Model**: haiku (simple chain triggering)

### Specialized Agents (Sonnet Model)

#### Code Quality Domain
- **code-reviewer**: Analysis-only code quality and security review
- **security-scanner**: OWASP vulnerability detection and analysis
- **test-automator**: Test creation and validation with execution
- **debugger**: Root cause analysis and fix implementation

#### Research Domain
- **technical-researcher**: External research and framework evaluation
- **ai-engineering-researcher**: AI/ML developments and research
- **context-engineer**: Context optimization and prompt improvement

#### Documentation Domain
- **smart-doc-generator**: README, API docs, comprehensive documentation
- **adr-creator**: Architectural Decision Record creation
- **pr-optimizer**: GitHub PR creation and optimization

#### GitHub Integration
- **github-checker**: Repository maintenance and status checks
- **dependency-manager**: Package updates and security alerts

### Analysis Agents (Sonnet/Haiku Models)

#### Read-Only Analyzers
- **test-coverage-analyzer**: Coverage analysis and gap identification
- **work-completion-summary**: Brief summaries and TTS integration

#### Meta Agents
- **meta-agent**: Agent creation and configuration generation

## Orchestration Patterns

### Pattern 1: Feature Development Chain

```yaml
Trigger: Complex feature request
Sequence:
  1. workflow-orchestrator (coordination planning)
  2. technical-researcher (external research)
  3. adr-creator (if architectural decisions needed)
  4. debugger or specialized implementation agent
  5. security-orchestrator (mandatory security validation)
      code-reviewer (security analysis)
      security-scanner (vulnerability detection)
  6. test-automator (test creation)
  7. smart-doc-generator (documentation updates)
```

### Pattern 2: Security Validation Chain (Mandatory)

```yaml
Trigger: ANY code modification
Mandatory Sequence:
  1. code-reviewer (read-only security analysis)
  2. security-orchestrator (chain coordination)
  3. security-scanner (vulnerability detection)

Result: BLOCK if security issues found, PROCEED if validated
```

### Pattern 3: Bug Investigation and Resolution

```yaml
Trigger: Error detection or bug report
Sequence:
  1. debugger (root cause analysis)
  2. technical-researcher (if external knowledge needed)
  3. Implementation (debugger or domain specialist)
  4. security-orchestrator (mandatory security check)
  5. test-automator (regression testing)
  6. smart-doc-generator (documentation updates)
```

## Tool Permissions

Tool allocation follows the **principle of least privilege** with role-based access control.

### Security Levels

#### read_only (Analysis Agents)
```yaml
Tools Allowed:
  - Read, Grep, Glob
  - Bash(git:*) # Only git commands
  - WebSearch, WebFetch
  - Task

Tools Forbidden:
  - Write, Edit, MultiEdit
  - Bash(*) # Except git commands

Risk Level: Low
Confirmation Required: No
```

#### write_limited (Content Creation Agents)
```yaml
Tools Allowed:
  - Read, Write, Edit, MultiEdit
  - Grep, Glob, Task

Tools Forbidden:
  - Bash(*) # No command execution
  - NotebookEdit

Risk Level: Medium
Confirmation Required: Yes
```

#### execution_restricted (GitHub/System Agents)
```yaml
Tools Allowed:
  - Read, Task
  - Bash(git:*, test:*, npm:*, gh:*, security:*)

Tools Forbidden:
  - Write, Edit
  - Bash(rm:*, sudo:*)

Risk Level: Medium
Confirmation Required: Yes
```

#### full_access (Orchestrators and Meta Agents)
```yaml
Tools Allowed: ["*"]
Tools Forbidden: []
Risk Level: High
Confirmation Required: Yes
```

### Agent-Specific Permissions

| Agent | Security Level | Key Tools | Rationale |
|-------|---------------|-----------|-----------|
| code-reviewer | read_only | Read, Grep, Bash(git diff) | Analysis only, no modification |
| security-scanner | read_only | Read, WebSearch, Bash(security) | Security analysis, no changes |
| smart-doc-generator | write_limited | Read, Write, MultiEdit | Documentation creation |
| debugger | execution_restricted | Read, Write, Bash | Analysis + fixes + debugging |
| workflow-orchestrator | full_access | * | Strategic coordination |
| meta-agent | full_access | * | Agent creation requires full access |

## Model Allocation

Model assignment based on **cognitive load complexity** (ADR-008).

### Allocation Matrix

#### Opus (High Cognitive Load)
**Complex reasoning, synthesis, creation, judgment**

- **meta-agent**: Agent creation requires deep pattern understanding
- **workflow-orchestrator**: Strategic multi-step coordination
- **technical-researcher**: Complex source synthesis and evaluation
- **adr-creator**: Architectural decision analysis
- **debugger**: Complex logical reasoning chains
- **context-engineer**: Nuanced AI behavior understanding

#### Sonnet (Medium Cognitive Load)
**Analysis, pattern matching, structured execution**

- **code-reviewer**: Code pattern recognition and analysis
- **security-scanner**: Vulnerability pattern matching
- **test-automator**: Test pattern generation and coverage
- **smart-doc-generator**: Structured content creation
- **ai-engineering-researcher**: Research synthesis within domain

#### Haiku (Low Cognitive Load)
**Simple tasks, formatting, checks, template operations**

- **github-checker**: Simple status checks and API calls
- **dependency-manager**: Version comparisons and updates
- **work-completion-summary**: Brief summaries and TTS
- **security-orchestrator**: Simple chain triggering
- **pr-optimizer**: Template filling and formatting

### Dynamic Upgrading

```python
# Confidence-based model escalation
if agent_confidence < 80% and current_model != "opus":
    escalate_to_higher_model()

# Context pressure handling
if context_compression > 70%:
    prefer_higher_capability_model()

# Error recovery
if task_failed and retries_remaining > 0:
    retry_with_next_tier_model()
```

## Chain Configuration

### Agent Orchestration Configuration

```yaml
# .claude/agents/config/agent-orchestration.yaml

chains:
  security_validation:
    description: "Mandatory security chain for code modifications"
    trigger: "code_change"
    mandatory: true
    sequence:
      - agent: "code-reviewer"
        tools: ["Read", "Grep", "Bash(git diff)"]
        timeout: 300
      - agent: "security-orchestrator"
        tools: ["Task", "Read"]
        timeout: 60
      - agent: "security-scanner"
        tools: ["Read", "WebSearch", "Bash(security)"]
        timeout: 600

  feature_development:
    description: "Complex feature implementation workflow"
    trigger: "feature_request"
    sequence:
      - agent: "workflow-orchestrator"
        parallel: false
      - agent: "technical-researcher"
        parallel: true
      - agent: "adr-creator"
        condition: "architectural_decision_needed"
      - chain: "security_validation"
        mandatory: true

  bug_resolution:
    description: "Bug investigation and fix workflow"
    trigger: "error_detected"
    sequence:
      - agent: "debugger"
        tools: ["Read", "Write", "Bash"]
      - chain: "security_validation"
        mandatory: true
      - agent: "test-automator"
        parallel: true
```

### Chain Execution Engine

```python
# .claude/agents/config/chain-executor.py

class ChainExecutor:
    def execute_chain(self, chain_name: str, context: dict):
        """Execute agent chain with validation and error handling."""

        # 1. Load chain configuration
        chain_config = self.load_chain_config(chain_name)

        # 2. Validate tool permissions
        for step in chain_config.sequence:
            self.validate_agent_tools(step.agent, step.tools)

        # 3. Execute sequence with context accumulation
        results = []
        for step in chain_config.sequence:
            if step.get('parallel'):
                result = self.execute_parallel(step, context)
            else:
                result = self.execute_sequential(step, context)

            context.update(result)
            results.append(result)

            # Check for blocking conditions
            if result.get('blocked'):
                return self.handle_chain_block(result, chain_name)

        return self.aggregate_results(results)
```

## Compliance Validation

### Validation Script Usage

```bash
# Quick compliance check
./.claude/hooks/check-agents.sh

# Detailed analysis with suggestions
./.claude/hooks/check-agents.sh --verbose

# What gets validated:
#  Hierarchical placement (orchestrators/, specialists/, analyzers/)
#  Tool allocation boundaries (3-7 tools per agent)
#  Model allocation rules (cognitive load matching)
#  Description format (ALWAYS/NEVER/RUNS AFTER/HANDS OFF TO)
#  Security chain integration
#  Agent chain configuration integrity
```

### Validation Categories

#### Architecture Compliance
- **Agent placement**: Correct subdirectory based on role
- **Naming conventions**: kebab-case filenames matching agent names
- **Hierarchy adherence**: Proper orchestrator  specialist  analyzer structure

#### Tool Security
- **Permission boundaries**: Agents only have necessary tools
- **Security isolation**: Read-only agents cannot modify files
- **Tool count limits**: 3-7 tools per agent for cognitive load optimization

#### Model Allocation
- **Complexity matching**: Model matches cognitive load requirements
- **Cost optimization**: No over-allocation of expensive models
- **Consistency**: Similar agents use similar models

#### Chain Integration
- **Security chains**: Mandatory security validation configured
- **Handoff patterns**: Proper agent-to-agent coordination
- **Error handling**: Fallback mechanisms defined

### Common Compliance Issues

```bash
 ISSUE: Agent has 12 tools (exceeds cognitive load limit of 7)
 FIX: Reduce to core tools or split into multiple specialized agents

 ISSUE: Read-only agent has Write tool access
 FIX: Remove Write tools, change to write_limited security level

 ISSUE: Simple task agent using opus model
 FIX: Change to sonnet or haiku based on cognitive complexity

 ISSUE: Missing security chain integration
 FIX: Add mandatory security validation handoff
```

## Best Practices

### Agent Selection Guidelines

1. **Complex multi-step tasks**  Use workflow-orchestrator
2. **Security-critical code**  Mandatory security chain (non-negotiable)
3. **Domain-specific work**  Use appropriate specialist
4. **Analysis-only tasks**  Use read-only analyzers
5. **Simple formatting**  Use haiku-model agents

### Orchestration Guidelines

1. **Plan workflows** with TodoWrite before agent delegation
2. **Respect tool boundaries** - never override security restrictions
3. **Chain mandatory validations** for security-critical operations
4. **Optimize model allocation** based on actual cognitive complexity
5. **Document decisions** in agent coordination workflows

### Error Handling

1. **Agent failures**  Retry with alternative agent or escalate model
2. **Security violations**  Immediately involve security-orchestrator
3. **Tool permission errors**  Check .claude/agents/config/tool-permissions.yaml
4. **Chain interruptions**  Resume from last successful checkpoint

This reference provides complete documentation for understanding, using, and extending the hierarchical multi-agent system in CC-Boilerplate.

content.text:
Based on my analysis of the agent roster, here's my recommendation for the OPTIMAL team composition for LLM testing and CLAUDE.md documentation:

##  Optimal Team Composition for LLM Testing & CLAUDE.md Documentation

### For LLM Testing Framework Design

#### Primary Specialists:

1. **context-engineer** (Opus model)
   - **Why**: Direct expertise in "Context optimization and prompt improvement"
   - **Relevance**: Understands nuanced AI behavior, prompt evaluation, and behavioral testing
   - **Perfect for**: Designing prompt evaluation frameworks and role adherence testing

2. **ai-engineering-researcher** (Sonnet model)
   - **Why**: Specializes in "AI/ML developments and research"
   - **Relevance**: Deep understanding of LLM behavior patterns and evaluation methodologies
   - **Perfect for**: Researching best practices for behavioral testing and regression patterns

3. **test-automator** (Sonnet model)
   - **Why**: "Test creation and validation with execution"
   - **Relevance**: Can create comprehensive test suites for prompt behavior
   - **Perfect for**: Implementing the actual testing framework and regression tests

4. **debugger** (Opus model)
   - **Why**: "Root cause analysis and fix implementation" with "Complex logical reasoning chains"
   - **Relevance**: Can analyze why prompts fail and identify behavioral drift
   - **Perfect for**: Debugging prompt failures and reasoning chain analysis

### For CLAUDE.md Documentation

#### Primary Specialists:

1. **meta-agent** (Opus model)
   - **Why**: "Agent creation requires deep pattern understanding" - has self-referential capabilities
   - **Relevance**: Best positioned to document AI priming and meta-cognitive patterns
   - **Perfect for**: Creating documentation that AI can understand about itself

2. **context-engineer** (Opus model) 
   - **Why**: Expert in context optimization and AI behavior understanding
   - **Relevance**: Can document reasoning chains and priming patterns with theoretical backing
   - **Perfect for**: Documenting optimal context structures and priming strategies

3. **adr-creator** (Opus model)
   - **Why**: "Architectural decision analysis" with deep reasoning capabilities
   - **Relevance**: Can document the WHY behind AI priming decisions with proper rationale
   - **Perfect for**: Creating ADRs for CLAUDE.md design decisions

4. **smart-doc-generator** (Sonnet model)
   - **Why**: "README, API docs, comprehensive documentation"
   - **Relevance**: Can structure and format the documentation systematically
   - **Perfect for**: Final documentation assembly and formatting

### Orchestration Strategy

**workflow-orchestrator** should coordinate this as a complex multi-step workflow:

```yaml
Phase 1: Research & Analysis
  - ai-engineering-researcher: LLM testing best practices
  - context-engineer: Prompt evaluation methodologies
  - meta-agent: Self-referential documentation patterns

Phase 2: Framework Design
  - context-engineer: Design prompt testing framework
  - test-automator: Create test structure
  - debugger: Design failure analysis patterns

Phase 3: Documentation Creation
  - meta-agent: Document AI priming theory
  - context-engineer: Document reasoning chains
  - adr-creator: Document architectural decisions
  - smart-doc-generator: Compile final documentation

Phase 4: Validation
  - security-orchestrator: Mandatory security validation
  - code-reviewer: Quality analysis
```

### Why These Agents Are BETTER Than Generic Options

1. **context-engineer** > generic prompt-engineer
   - Specifically designed for "nuanced AI behavior understanding"
   - Opus model for complex cognitive tasks
   - Direct expertise in prompt optimization

2. **meta-agent** > generic documentation agents
   - Self-referential capabilities perfect for AI documenting AI
   - "Deep pattern understanding" essential for meta-cognitive documentation
   - Can create agents, so understands agent priming deeply

3. **ai-engineering-researcher** > technical-researcher
   - Specialized in AI/ML domain vs general technical research
   - Better suited for LLM-specific testing methodologies

4. **debugger** with "reasoning chain" expertise > generic testers
   - Can analyze WHY prompts fail, not just that they fail
   - Complex logical reasoning perfect for behavioral analysis

Links: [{"title":"LLM Evaluation Metrics: The Ultimate LLM Evaluation Guide - Confident AI","url":"https://www.confident-ai.com/blog/llm-evaluation-metrics-everything-you-need-for-llm-evaluation"},{"title":"LLM evaluation: Metrics, frameworks, and best practices","url":"https://wandb.ai/onlineinference/genai-research/reports/LLM-evaluation-Metrics-frameworks-and-best-practices--VmlldzoxMTMxNjQ4NA"},{"title":"Building an LLM evaluation framework: best practices | Datadog","url":"https://www.datadoghq.com/blog/llm-evaluation-framework-best-practices/"},{"title":"LLM Testing in 2025: Top Methods and Strategies","url":"https://www.confident-ai.com/blog/llm-testing-in-2024-top-methods-and-strategies"},{"title":"LLM Evaluation: Frameworks, Metrics, and Best Practices | SuperAnnotate","url":"https://www.superannotate.com/blog/llm-evaluation-guide"},{"title":"Evaluation metrics | Microsoft Learn","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ai/playbook/technology-guidance/generative-ai/working-with-llms/evaluation/list-of-eval-metrics"},{"title":"LLM evaluation metrics and methods","url":"https://www.evidentlyai.com/llm-guide/llm-evaluation-metrics"},{"title":"Evaluating Large Language Model (LLM) systems: Metrics, challenges, and best practices | by Jane Huang | Data Science at Microsoft | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/data-science-at-microsoft/evaluating-llm-systems-metrics-challenges-and-best-practices-664ac25be7e5"},{"title":"LLM Evaluation: Metrics, Methodologies, Best Practices | DataCamp","url":"https://www.datacamp.com/blog/llm-evaluation"},{"title":"Best 10 LLM Evaluation Tools in 2025 (Updated)","url":"https://www.deepchecks.com/best-llm-evaluation-tools/"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of LLM prompt evaluation testing methodologies for 2024-2025 with a focus on behavioral consistency metrics:

## Key LLM Evaluation Methodologies (2024-2025)

### 1. **Behavioral Consistency Testing Approaches**

SelfCheckGPT is a sampling-based approach that assumes hallucinated outputs are not reproducible, whereas if an LLM has knowledge of a given concept, sampled responses are likely to be similar and contain consistent facts. It generates multiple responses to the same prompt and compares them for consistency, flagging hallucinations if answers diverge.(no content)The NLI (Natural Language Inference) scorer uses NLP classification models to classify whether an LLM output is logically consistent (entailment), contradictory, or unrelated (neutral) with respect to a given reference text, with scores ranging between entailment (value of 1) and contradiction (value of 0), providing a measure of logical coherence.

### 2. **Core Evaluation Frameworks**

A number of evaluation approaches, including code-based, LLM-as-a-judge, and human-in-the-loop methods, can be considered when building evaluation frameworks.(no content)Frameworks for evaluation prompts include Reason-then-Score (RTS), Multiple Choice Question Scoring (MCQ), Head-to-head scoring (H2H), and G-Eval.(no content)G-EVAL combines Chain-of-Thought with form-based evaluations, where the model first generates step-by-step instructions tailored to specific criteria. FineSurE decomposes complex evaluations (e.g., faithfulness, completeness) into discrete criteria and uses fact-by-fact checking.

### 3. **Testing Categories and Metrics**

Unit tests make up functional, performance, and responsibility tests, which together make up a regression test for LLMs. Unit testing involves testing the smallest testable parts of an application, which for LLMs means evaluating an LLM response for a given input based on clearly defined criteria, such as whether a summary contains enough information and whether it contains any hallucinations from the original text.(no content)Metrics should always compute a score when evaluating the task at hand. This approach enables you to set a minimum passing threshold to determine if your LLM application is "good enough" and allows you to monitor how these scores change over time as you iterate and improve your implementation.

### 4. **Production Monitoring and Continuous Evaluation**

Running continuous evaluation cycles with regular check-ins on your model's performance helps catch any issues early on. This ongoing process keeps your LLM sharp and ready to adapt.(no content)Run automated LLM-based scoring to have another AI model evaluate on relevancy, safety, or for specific requirements. This lets you keep an eye on performance all the time without having humans review every single output.(no content)Instead of evaluating every single output, evaluate a reasonable sample - usually 1-5% of random outputs from production. Add to this by specifically checking outputs that users gave a thumbs down, plus categories you know tend to have problems.

### 5. **Behavioral Consistency Specific Metrics**

Coherence helps analyze the logical flow and consistency of the generated text. A coherent text maintains a clear structure and logical progression of ideas, making it straightforward for readers to follow. Coherence is particularly important for longer texts, such as essays or articles, where maintaining a consistent narrative is key.(no content)The needle-in-the-haystack test is a common code-based approach for evaluating context retrieval, and faithfulness evaluations are typically produced to evaluate LLMs' self-consistency within an LLM-as-a-judge framework.

### 6. **Best Practices for 2024-2025**

Having straightforward and consistent metrics is key. Think about what really matters for your model  like how helpful or relevant its responses are. These metrics need to be agreed upon by parties involved, making sure they match the real-world needs the LLM serves.(no content)Regularly compare how your AI judges perform against human reviewers to make sure they're staying accurate and consistent. AI judges are powerful tools that can handle evaluation at scale, but only when you combine them with human oversight, regular checking, and careful design. Using automated and human evaluation together strategically helps you build trustworthy AI systems while keeping quality high.(no content)To get an even more accurate evaluation, you can run multiple experiments and compare aggregate evaluations of one experiment to another experiment. To monitor evaluations in production, teams can use a pipeline to log live LLM requests including prompts, responses, and metadata such as user feedback and session ID.

These methodologies represent the state-of-the-art approaches for evaluating LLM prompts with a particular emphasis on ensuring behavioral consistency across different scenarios and maintaining reliable performance in production environments.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about prompt testing, role adherence, and AI agent behavior evaluation from 2024-2025:

## Key Findings on Prompt Testing and Role Adherence in AI Agent Evaluation (2024-2025)

### Role Adherence Metrics and Frameworks

The role adherence metric is a conversational metric that determines whether your LLM chatbot is able to adhere to its given role throughout a conversation, particularly useful for role-playing use cases.(no content)The Role Adherence score is calculated by dividing the number of assistant turns that adhered to the chatbot role by the total number of assistant turns in conversation.

### Current Trends in AI Agent Evaluation (2024-2025)

AI Agent Evaluation now sits at the center of every serious AI rollout, as modern AI Agents reshape humancomputer interaction through large-language-model power and smart tool use, though without structured evaluation, these autonomous systems can misfire.(no content)Future AGI's approach includes Function Calling Assessment and Prompt Adherence checks combined with quality filters to help teams build safer, smarter agents that truly serve users.

### Adversarial Testing and Security Concerns

Research from 2024 presents critical evaluation of the resilience and cybersecurity efficacy of leading AI models including ChatGPT-4, Bard, Claude, and Microsoft Copilot, using innovative adversarial prompts designed to rigorously test content moderation capabilities and introducing the Response Quality Score (RQS) metric.(no content)The adversarial prompts employed primarily exploit the models' role adherence and responses in hypothetical scenarios.(no content)At the output stage of AI systems, using a secondary LLM to critique and review responses ensures adherence to ethical and legal standards through an approach known as Constitutional AI, which involves setting predefined criteria for acceptable responses.

### Enterprise Tools and Platforms (2024)

72% of companies using AI collaboration tools saw productivity gains in 2024, though much improvement stems from workflow automation rather than tools specifically built for refining prompts, with platforms focusing on application-level regulatory compliance rather than detailed governance for prompt engineering.(no content)PromptLayer and similar platforms allow teams to version, test, and monitor every prompt and agent with robust evals, tracing, and regression sets, including the ability to rigorously test prompts before deploying with human and AI graders and trigger evals to run every time a prompt is updated.

### Systematic Evaluation Approaches

As Generative AI workloads move to production, the forest of prompts can quickly become impossible to navigate and maintain, with prompt quality able to make or break an AI system, necessitating methods for automatically and systematically evaluating and improving prompts at scale.(no content)The importance of effective prompt optimization through prompt engineering has become key to efficiently balancing quality of outputs, response time, and costs, with high-quality prompts maximizing chances of good responses from generative AI models, making prompt evaluation a critical aspect of developing high-quality AI-powered solutions.

### Testing Methodologies

Pointwise prompt testing involves evaluating a prompt independently based on predefined criteria such as accuracy, recall, precision, coherence, or relevance, with a prompt's response analyzed in isolation without direct comparison with others.(no content)Best practices include being as specific as possible in prompts and evaluation criteria, testing edge cases with a variety of inputs to verify robustness, and running multiple evaluations on the same prompt for comparing and testing output consistency.

### Future Outlook

In the future, testers who master prompt engineering will become even more valuable, with the role shifting from executing manual tests to strategically guiding AI to automate a broader range of testing tasks, integrating functional, performance, load, and accessibility testing into a single, seamless flow.

The research indicates that prompt testing and role adherence evaluation have become critical components of AI agent development in 2024-2025, with increasing focus on systematic evaluation frameworks, security considerations, and the development of specialized tools for prompt management and testing at scale.

Based on the search results, I can provide information about CEO role delegation testing, AI behavioral evaluation metrics, and contrarian discipline testing:

## CEO Role Delegation and AI in Decision-Making

Organizations are implementing federated governance models for AI management, where leaders can directly oversee high-risk issues while setting direction and delegating other monitoring to business units. This includes measuring performance-based criteria such as accuracy, speed, and scalability.

Unlike humans, AI systems (LLMs) do not experience social inhibitions when debating with authority figures, such as a CEO, which allows for more exhaustive and unbiased analysis.

## AI Behavioral Evaluation Metrics

Organizations are encouraged to perform continuous testing and evaluation of all AI system components and features where bias can contribute to harmful impacts. If during deployment the model is retrained with new data, the model deployer should work with the model producer to assess actual performance for bias evaluation.

AI benchmarks serve as powerful tools to quantitatively assess, compare, and improve the performance of different AI models, algorithms, and systems.

Research shows that managers' performance ratings are impacted by the presence of an AI recommendation, demonstrating anchoring and adjustment bias in AI-assisted decision making.

## Contrarian Discipline Testing

The devil's advocate is a strategic decision-making (SDM) tool that involves assigning someone to review a strategic plan and provide thorough critiques of its main assumptions and arguments, which can be used for both strategy generation and evaluation.

Managers can effectively use AI as a devil's advocate because traditionally, employing this approach is resource intensive, requiring days of work from skilled personnel, while an LLM reduces these costs, allowing more frequent use.

AI is less encumbered by social considerations or cognitive dissonance when offering contrarian viewpoints and can help overcome cognitive biases and organizational inertia.

In practical application, when given a business school strategic plan, an LLM generated 15 contrarian arguments, including concerns about the volatile nature of technology, ethical issues with investing in student start-ups, and accreditation challenges.

## Key Considerations

Interdisciplinary and multi-stakeholder approaches are essential for achieving transparency and accountability in AI systems, requiring collaboration between computer science, law, ethics, and social science disciplines, with engagement from policymakers, industry leaders, civil society organizations, and the general public.

Current perceptions about the role and responsibility of humans-in-the-loop with AI are often implicit, with expectations about performance often based on untested or outdated hypotheses.

These findings suggest that organizations are actively developing frameworks for testing AI behavioral patterns, implementing contrarian testing methodologies to challenge assumptions, and creating delegation structures that balance human oversight with AI autonomy in decision-making processes.

Based on the search results, I can provide comprehensive information about similarity metrics for LLM evaluation, particularly for conversation logs, automated testing, and data formats like CSV/JSON in 2024-2025.

## Key Similarity Metrics for LLM Evaluation

LLM evaluation metrics such as answer correctness, semantic similarity, and hallucination, are metrics that score an LLM system's output based on criteria you care about.

### Main Types of Similarity Metrics

1. **Semantic Similarity Metrics**
   - The semantic similarity between two sentences refers to how closely related their meanings are. To do that, each string is first represented as a feature vector that captures its semantics/meanings. One commonly used approach is generating embeddings of the strings (for example, using an LLM) and then using cosine similarity to measure the similarity between the two embedding vectors.
   
2. **BERTScore**
   - The BERTScore scorer, which relies on pre-trained language models like BERT and computes the cosine similarity between the contextual embeddings of words in the reference and the generated texts. These similarities are then aggregated to produce a final score. A higher BERTScore indicates a greater degree of semantic overlap between the LLM output and the reference text.
   - BERTScore evaluates texts by comparing the similarity of contextual embeddings from models like BERT, focusing more on meaning than exact word matches.

3. **Traditional Text Similarity Metrics**
   - Metrics BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy), ROUGE (Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation), and JS divergence (JS2) are overlap-based metrics that measure the similarity of the output text and the reference text using n-grams.
   - The Levenshtein Similarity Ratio is a string metric for measuring the similarity between two sequences. This measure is based on Levenshtein Distance. Informally, the Levenshtein Distance between two strings is the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) required to change one string into the other.

4. **Advanced Embedding-Based Metrics**
   - The MoverScore scorer, which first uses embedding models, specifically pre-trained language models like BERT to obtain deeply contextualized word embeddings for both the reference text and the generated text before using something called the Earth Mover's Distance (EMD) to compute the minimal cost
   - BERTScore, MoverScore, and Sentence Mover Similarity (SMS) metrics all rely on contextualized embeddings to measure the similarity between two texts.

## Implementation for Automated Testing in 2024-2025

### Using G-Eval for Semantic Similarity
Again, you can use G-Eval to calculate the degree of semantic similarity. This is especially useful for longer text, where traditional NLP metrics that overlook semantics fall short.

### Data Format Support
Format Validation: Evaluators such as is-json, is-code, and is-csv confirm whether the model output adheres to a specified structure.(no content)Allows you to generate synthetic datasets using your knowledge base as context, or load datasets from CSVs, JSONs, or Hugging face.

## Best Practices for 2025

1. **Multi-Metric Approach**: The choice of which LLM evaluation metric to use depends on the use case and architecture of your LLM application. Our experience tells us that you don't want more than 5 LLM evaluation metrics in your evaluation pipeline.

2. **Reference-Based vs Reference-Free**: Reference-based LLM evaluation methods compare responses to known ground truth answers using exact matching, word overlap, embedding similarity, or LLMs as judges. Reference-free LLM evaluation methods assess outputs through proxy metrics and custom criteria using regular expressions, text statistics, programmatic validation, custom LLM judges, and ML-based scoring.

3. **LLM-as-Judge Methods**: LLM as a judge is one of the most popular methods. It prompts an LLM to score outputs based on custom criteria and can handle conversation-level evaluations.

## Tools and Frameworks for 2025

Top evaluation frameworks mentioned include:
- **DeepEval**: Open-source framework supporting CSV/JSON data loading
- **Patronus**: Includes conversational quality evaluators for dialogue-level behaviors
- **Confident AI**: Provides comprehensive metrics for LLM evaluation
- **MLflow**: Modular package for evaluation pipelines

These tools support automated testing workflows and can process conversation logs in various formats including CSV and JSON, making them suitable for production deployments in 2024-2025.

## Key Findings on Prompt Regression Testing and LLM Evaluation in 2025

### Regression Testing for LLMs

Regression testing involves evaluating an LLM on the same set of test cases every time you make an iteration to safeguard against breaking changes. The upside of using a quantitative LLM evaluation metric for LLM evaluation is that we can set clear thresholds to define what is considered a "breaking change", and also monitor how the performance of your LLM changes through multiple iterations.(no content)Even when your product is live, you need offline evaluations to run LLM regression tests. They let you verify that the changes you make don't introduce new (or old) issues.(no content)Systematic LLM regression testing helps you safely build on top of existing systems. You can make changes while making sure you're not creating new problems along the way.

### Conversation Regression Testing

A notable research development is the concept of Conversation Regression Testing. Based on sample conversations with a baseline chatbot, Conversation Regression Testing tracks how conversational errors persist or are resolved by applying different prompt strategies.(no content)This technique is embodied in an interactive design tool, BotDesigner, that lets designers identify archetypal errors across multiple conversations; shows common threads of conversation using a graph visualization.

### Automated Evaluation Methods

Automated LLM evals can be reference-based: you compare outputs to a known ground truth during experimentation, regression testing, and stress-testing. Reference-free automated LLM evals assess outputs directly and are commonly used in production monitoring, guardrails, and complex conversational scenarios.

### LLM-as-a-Judge

LLM as a judge is one of the most popular methods. It prompts an LLM to score outputs based on custom criteria and can handle conversation-level evaluations.(no content)LLM-as-a-judge is an evaluation approach that supports all these workflows. The idea is simple: ask an LLM to "judge" the text outputs using guidelines you define.

### Conversation Analysis Techniques

Entire conversation evaluation involves looking at the entire conversation and evaluating it based on all turns in a conversation. Last best response evaluation involves evaluating only the last response an LLM chatbot generates in a conversation.(no content)The principle remains the same: for whichever type of conversation evaluation you decide to adopt, it should be carried out with the context of the prior turns in mind.

### 2025 Tools and Platforms

Several prominent platforms are leading the field in 2025:

1. **DeepEval**: Benchmark LLM systems to optimize on prompts, models, and catch regressions with metrics powered by DeepEval.(no content)DeepEval is an open-source LLM evaluation framework built to streamline the benchmarking of LLMs. Designed with developers in mind, it offers a unit-test-style interface for defining custom evaluations, making it easy to integrate with CI/CD pipelines. Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of prompt regression testing, LLM automated evaluation, and conversation analysis in 2025:

## Key Findings on LLM Evaluation and Regression Testing in 2025

### Prompt Regression Testing

Regression testing involves evaluating an LLM on the same set of test cases every time you make an iteration to safeguard against breaking changes. The upside of using a quantitative LLM evaluation metric for LLM evaluation is, we can set clear thresholds to define what is considered a "breaking change", and also monitor how the performance of your LLM changes through multiple iterations.(no content)Even when your product is live, you need offline evaluations to run LLM regression tests. They let you verify that the changes you make don't introduce new (or old) issues. Systematic LLM regression testing helps you safely build on top of existing system. You can make changes while making sure you're not creating new problems along the way.

### Conversation Regression Testing

To address this challenge, we introduce the concept of Conversation Regression Testing. Based on sample conversations with a baseline chatbot, Conversation Regression Testing tracks how conversational errors persist or are resolved by applying different prompt strategies.(no content)We embody this technique in an interactive design tool, BotDesigner, that lets designers identify archetypal errors across multiple conversations; shows common threads of conversation using a graph visualization; and highlights the effects of prompt changes across bot design iterations.

### Automated LLM Evaluation Methods

Automated LLM evals can be reference-based: you compare outputs to a known ground truth during experimentation, regression testing, and stress-testing. Reference-free automated LLM evals assess outputs directly and are commonly used in production monitoring, guardrails, and complex conversational scenarios.(no content)LLM-as-a-judge is an evaluation approach that supports all these workflows. The idea is simple: ask an LLM to "judge" the text outputs using guidelines you define.

### Conversation Analysis and Testing

Entire conversation evaluation: This involves looking at the entire conversation and evaluating it based on all turns in a conversation. Last best response evaluation: This involves evaluating only the last response an LLM chatbot generates in a conversation. The principle remains the same: for whichever type of conversation evaluation you decide to adopt, it should be carried out with the context of the prior turns in mind.(no content)LLM as a judge is one of the most popular methods. It prompts an LLM to score outputs based on custom criteria and can handle conversation-level evaluations.

### Key Tools and Platforms in 2025

1. **DeepEval**: Benchmark LLM systems to optimize on prompts, models, and catch regressions with metrics powered by DeepEval.

2. **Confident AI**: DeepEval comes with an optional, dedicated platform called Confident AI (sign up here), and when you run more than one test run when using Confident AI + DeepEval, you get a side-by-side comparison tool that you can use to catch regressions/identify improvements.

3. **Evidently AI**: Test fast, ship faster. Evidently Cloud gives you reliable, repeatable evaluations for complex systems like RAG and agents  so you can iterate quickly and ship with confidence.

### Testing Strategies

It is vital a robust testing approach can be used to evaluate and regression test LLM systems at scale. Unit tests make up functional, performance, and responsibility tests, of which they together make up a regression test for your LLM.(no content)It is cost effective and suitable for pre-deployment checks and regression testing.

### Real-time Monitoring and Production Evaluation

Inside, these checks are the same reference-free LLM evals but built directly into your app and applied in real time.(no content)Performance & quality monitoring: Orq.ai provides real-time visibility into how agentic systems behave in production. Teams can monitor granular LLM performance metrics, identify regressions, and compare experiment variants side-by-side across latency, cost, and quality dimensions.

The field in 2025 shows significant advancement in automated evaluation techniques, with emphasis on systematic regression testing, conversation-level analysis, and the widespread adoption of LLM-as-judge approaches for scalable evaluation across different stages of development and production.

Based on my search results, I haven't found specific information about a "worst idea in the room" methodology for AI testing. However, I found relevant information about contrarian and adversarial validation frameworks used in AI testing. Let me provide you with what I discovered:

## AI Testing and Validation Frameworks

### Adversarial Validation Approaches

Adversarial training frameworks are being used in AI testing to mitigate biases that may have been acquired through data collection, with demonstrable improvements in outcome fairness without compromising performance. Adversarial validation is used to test whether training and test datasets follow the same underlying distribution.

Most machine learning models are validated on fixed datasets, which can give an incomplete picture of model capabilities and weaknesses that may only be revealed during real-world deployment. Researchers have developed methods to find adversarial synthetic examples that can fool contemporary models, demonstrating weaknesses not measured by commonly used validation datasets.

### Current AI Testing Methodologies

Validation methods for AI systems have been synthesized into a taxonomy consisting of trial, simulation, model-centered validation, and expert opinion. Approaches to AI verification and validation include formal methods (formal proofs, model checking, probabilistic verification), software testing, simulation-based testing and experiments.

Adversarial testing involves exposing AI models to malicious inputs to test their robustness, such as testing AI vision systems with distorted images to check for misclassification.

### Contrarian Testing Concepts

Some testing approaches include checking for inconsistency with desired behavior and systematically searching for worst-case outcomes when testing consistency with specifications. This appears to be the closest concept to a "worst idea" methodology, though it's not explicitly named as such.

Modern AI validation uses algorithmic AI red teaming, which sends thousands of inputs to a model and automatically analyzes susceptibility across hundreds of attack techniques and threat categories, then recommends necessary guardrails for safe deployment.

### Key Testing Standards

NIST conducts evaluations of AI including designing tasks, challenge problems, testbeds, developing technical guidelines and practices, and contributing to voluntary consensus-based standards for measuring and evaluating AI.

While I didn't find a specific "worst idea in the room" methodology, the concept appears similar to adversarial testing and red teaming approaches that deliberately try to find failure modes and edge cases in AI systems. These contrarian validation frameworks focus on discovering what could go wrong rather than confirming what works correctly.

content.text:
Based on my comprehensive research, I'll provide you with research-backed recommendations for a testing framework to evaluate CLAUDE.md prompt effectiveness. Let me present my findings:

# Executive Summary: LLM Prompt Testing Methodologies for CLAUDE.md Evaluation

## Key Research Findings

### 1. Industry Best Practices (2024-2025)

**Leading AI Companies' Approaches:**
- **Multi-metric evaluation frameworks** with no more than 5 core metrics to avoid complexity
- **LLM-as-a-Judge methodology** has become the gold standard for behavioral consistency testing
- **Regression testing pipelines** integrated into CI/CD workflows for prompt evolution tracking
- **Reference-free evaluation** for production monitoring and real-time behavioral assessment

**Critical Metrics for Behavioral Consistency:**
- **Role Adherence Score**: Measures percentage of responses that maintain assigned role throughout conversation
- **Semantic Similarity**: Using BERTScore and embedding-based metrics for behavioral pattern detection
- **Coherence Metrics**: Track logical flow and consistency across multi-turn conversations
- **Constitutional AI scoring**: Secondary LLM evaluation for adherence to predefined behavioral criteria

### 2. CLAUDE.md-Specific Testing Requirements

**CEO Role Adherence Testing:**
- **Delegation Pattern Detection**: Automated analysis of whether responses delegate vs. attempt direct implementation
- **Decision Framework Compliance**: Verification that responses follow the 5-step contrarian discipline process
- **Authority Pattern Recognition**: Testing for appropriate executive-level language and decision-making patterns

**Contrarian Discipline Verification:**
- **Devil's Advocate Testing**: LLMs excel at providing contrarian viewpoints without social inhibitions
- **Assumption Challenge Detection**: Automated scoring of whether responses include assumption questioning
- **Alternative Generation Assessment**: Measuring if responses provide multiple viable approaches

### 3. Technical Implementation Framework

**Optimal Data Format:**
- **JSON over CSV** for complex conversational data with nested structures
- **Conversation logs with metadata**: Include session ID, turn number, user feedback, and behavioral tags
- **Structured evaluation schemas** supporting both reference-based and reference-free assessment

**Key Implementation Components:**

```json
{
  "conversation_id": "uuid",
  "turn_number": 1,
  "prompt_version": "claude_md_v1.2",
  "user_input": "...",
  "ai_response": "...",
  "behavioral_scores": {
    "role_adherence": 0.95,
    "delegation_pattern": 0.87,
    "contrarian_discipline": 0.72,
    "ceo_language_pattern": 0.91
  },
  "evaluation_metadata": {
    "evaluator": "llm-as-judge",
    "timestamp": "2025-01-21T10:30:00Z"
  }
}
```

## Research-Backed Testing Framework Recommendations

### Core Testing Architecture

**1. Conversation Regression Testing (Based on arXiv:2302.03154)**
- Track how behavioral errors persist or resolve across prompt iterations
- Use graph visualization to identify archetypal failure patterns
- Implement automated detection of "CEO role drift" across conversation turns

**2. Multi-Level Evaluation Pipeline**
```
Level 1: Real-time Behavioral Guards (Production)
 Delegation pattern detection
 Role adherence scoring
 Emergency intervention triggers

Level 2: Batch Conversation Analysis (Daily)
 Semantic similarity clustering
 Contrarian discipline assessment
 Decision framework compliance

Level 3: Deep Behavioral Analysis (Weekly)
 Cross-conversation pattern analysis
 Prompt evolution impact assessment
 A/B testing for prompt improvements
```

**3. Similarity Metrics Implementation**
- **BERTScore** for semantic behavioral consistency
- **Embedding cosine similarity** for decision-making pattern matching
- **Custom CEO-role embeddings** trained on executive communication patterns
- **Constitutional AI scoring** for adherence to defined behavioral principles

### Automated Testing Implementation

**Regression Testing Pipeline:**
- **Pre-deployment checks** using unit test frameworks (DeepEval recommended)
- **Breaking change thresholds** set at <0.85 role adherence or <0.80 delegation pattern scores
- **Continuous monitoring** with 1-5% sampling of production conversations
- **Alert systems** for behavioral drift detection

**Key Tools Stack (2025 Leaders):**
- **DeepEval**: Open-source framework with CI/CD integration
- **Confident AI**: Production monitoring and side-by-side comparison
- **Custom LLM-as-Judge**: Fine-tuned evaluator for CEO role patterns
- **Graph visualization tools**: For conversation flow analysis

### Validation Methodologies

**"Worst Case" Testing (Contrarian Validation):**
- **Stress testing scenarios**: High-pressure situations requiring executive decision-making
- **Edge case conversations**: Complex multi-stakeholder scenarios
- **Adversarial inputs**: Attempts to break role adherence or delegation patterns
- **Red team exercises**: Systematic attempts to exploit behavioral weaknesses

**Metrics That Truly Matter:**
1. **Role Consistency Score** (0-1): Percentage of responses maintaining CEO role
2. **Delegation Effectiveness** (0-1): Ratio of appropriate delegations to direct attempts
3. **Contrarian Discipline Adherence** (0-1): Compliance with 5-step decision framework
4. **Executive Language Pattern** (0-1): Appropriateness of authority and decision-making language
5. **Behavioral Drift Detection** (regression metric): Change in behavioral patterns over time

### Implementation Roadmap

**Phase 1: Foundation (Weeks 1-2)**
- Implement basic role adherence scoring using LLM-as-Judge
- Set up conversation logging with behavioral metadata
- Create initial test dataset with ground truth behavioral labels

**Phase 2: Automated Pipeline (Weeks 3-4)**
- Deploy regression testing framework with CI/CD integration
- Implement real-time behavioral guards for production
- Set up alerting for behavioral drift detection

**Phase 3: Advanced Analytics (Weeks 5-6)**
- Deploy conversation regression testing with graph visualization
- Implement contrarian discipline automated assessment
- Create A/B testing framework for prompt evolution

### Risk Mitigation

**Key Risks and Mitigations:**
- **False positives in role detection**: Use ensemble scoring with multiple evaluator LLMs
- **Behavioral drift over time**: Implement adaptive thresholds based on rolling averages
- **Edge case failures**: Maintain human-in-the-loop validation for high-stakes scenarios
- **Evaluation bias**: Regular comparison of AI judges against human expert assessment

This framework provides a KISS-compliant but rigorous approach to continuously evaluate whether CLAUDE.md changes improve or degrade AI behavioral consistency, with specific focus on CEO role adherence and contrarian discipline validation.

## Research-Backed Testing Framework Recommendations

### Core Testing Architecture

**1. Conversation Regression Testing (Based on arXiv:2302.03154)**
- Track how behavioral errors persist or resolve across prompt iterations
- Use graph visualization to identify archetypal failure patterns
- Implement automated detection of "CEO role drift" across conversation turns

**2. Multi-Level Evaluation Pipeline**
```
Level 1: Real-time Behavioral Guards (Production)
 Delegation pattern detection
 Role adherence scoring
 Emergency intervention triggers

Level 2: Batch Conversation Analysis (Daily)
 Semantic similarity clustering
 Contrarian discipline assessment
 Decision framework compliance

Level 3: Deep Behavioral Analysis (Weekly)
 Cross-conversation pattern analysis
 Prompt evolution impact assessment
 A/B testing for prompt improvements
```

**3. Similarity Metrics Implementation**
- **BERTScore** for semantic behavioral consistency
- **Embedding cosine similarity** for decision-making pattern matching
- **Custom CEO-role embeddings** trained on executive communication patterns
- **Constitutional AI scoring** for adherence to defined behavioral principles

### Automated Testing Implementation

**Regression Testing Pipeline:**
- **Pre-deployment checks** using unit test frameworks (DeepEval recommended)
- **Breaking change thresholds** set at <0.85 role adherence or <0.80 delegation pattern scores
- **Continuous monitoring** with 1-5% sampling of production conversations
- **Alert systems** for behavioral drift detection

**Key Tools Stack (2025 Leaders):**
- **DeepEval**: Open-source framework with CI/CD integration
- **Confident AI**: Production monitoring and side-by-side comparison
- **Custom LLM-as-Judge**: Fine-tuned evaluator for CEO role patterns
- **Graph visualization tools**: For conversation flow analysis

### Validation Methodologies

**"Worst Case" Testing (Contrarian Validation):**
- **Stress testing scenarios**: High-pressure situations requiring executive decision-making
- **Edge case conversations**: Complex multi-stakeholder scenarios
- **Adversarial inputs**: Attempts to break role adherence or delegation patterns
- **Red team exercises**: Systematic attempts to exploit behavioral weaknesses

**Metrics That Truly Matter:**
1. **Role Consistency Score** (0-1): Percentage of responses maintaining CEO role
2. **Delegation Effectiveness** (0-1): Ratio of appropriate delegations to direct attempts
3. **Contrarian Discipline Adherence** (0-1): Compliance with 5-step decision framework
4. **Executive Language Pattern** (0-1): Appropriateness of authority and decision-making language
5. **Behavioral Drift Detection** (regression metric): Change in behavioral patterns over time

### Implementation Roadmap

**Phase 1: Foundation (Weeks 1-2)**
- Implement basic role adherence scoring using LLM-as-Judge
- Set up conversation logging with behavioral metadata
- Create initial test dataset with ground truth behavioral labels

**Phase 2: Automated Pipeline (Weeks 3-4)**
- Deploy regression testing framework with CI/CD integration
- Implement real-time behavioral guards for production
- Set up alerting for behavioral drift detection

**Phase 3: Advanced Analytics (Weeks 5-6)**
- Deploy conversation regression testing with graph visualization
- Implement contrarian discipline automated assessment
- Create A/B testing framework for prompt evolution

### Risk Mitigation

**Key Risks and Mitigations:**
- **False positives in role detection**: Use ensemble scoring with multiple evaluator LLMs
- **Behavioral drift over time**: Implement adaptive thresholds based on rolling averages
- **Edge case failures**: Maintain human-in-the-loop validation for high-stakes scenarios
- **Evaluation bias**: Regular comparison of AI judges against human expert assessment

This framework provides a KISS-compliant but rigorous approach to continuously evaluate whether CLAUDE.md changes improve or degrade AI behavioral consistency, with specific focus on CEO role adherence and contrarian discipline validation.

**CEO Role Adherence Patterns:**

**Contrarian Discipline Examples:**
- 5-step mandatory process before decisions: Assassinate Assumptions, Red Team Self, Force Alternatives, Stress Test, Risk Forecast
- "What's the strongest argument against this approach?" as standard practice
- Challenge every step against value-add with 95% certainty threshold

- Integration of contrarian thinking as organizational discipline

- Balance between KISS principles and comprehensive decision-making
- Protection of organizational focus through YAGNI enforcement

     6## Status
     7
     8Status: IN_PROGRESS
     9Status_Date: 2025-09-19
    10Status_Note: Spec files created: [0;32m[SPEC-GEN][0m, Creating, 2, specs, for, components:, frontend, backend, [0;32m[SPEC-GEN][0m, Creating, component, spec:, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-frontend/spec.md, [0;32m[SPEC-GEN][0m, , Created:, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-frontend/spec.md, [0;32m[SPEC-GEN][0m, Creating, component, spec:, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-backend/spec.md, [0;32m[SPEC-GEN][0m, , Created:, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-backend/spec.md, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-frontend/spec.md, specs/004-agent-system-redesign-backend/spec.md. Ready for /plan phase.
    11
    12## Goal
    13
    14**Feature Goal**: Transform the Claude Code sub-agent system from flat agent delegation to hierarchical orchestration with autonomous agent selection, security-first tool allocation, and proactive quality assurance through soft hooks.
    15
    16**Deliverable**:
    17
    18- Hierarchical orchestration system with primary orchestrator agents
    19- Security-based tool allocation matrix with role-based permissions
    20- Missing critical agents (debugger, security-scanner, dependency-manager, pr-optimizer, context-engineer)
    21- Soft hook system for drift prevention
    22- Cognitive load-based model allocation strategy
    23- Agent orchestration chains for common workflows
    24
    25**Success Definition**:
    26
    27- Agents autonomously coordinate in chains (code-reviewer  security-scanner  test-automator)
    28- Tool permissions enforced by role (read-only agents cannot edit)
    29- Proactive quality hooks prevent issues before they occur
    30- Model allocation optimizes cost vs complexity
    31- One-pass implementation success through comprehensive context
    32
    33## User Persona
    34
    35**Target User**: Claude Code users working on complex software projects requiring multi-step workflows, security validation, and code quality assurance
    36
    37**Use Case**: Developer writes code, system automatically triggers code-reviewer  security-scanner  test-automator chain, prevents insecure code from reaching production, and optimizes agent model usage based on task complexity
    38
    39**User Journey**:
    40
    411. User makes code change
    422. Soft hook triggers proactive quality chain
    433. Hierarchical agents coordinate automatically
    444. Security boundaries enforced throughout
    455. User receives comprehensive feedback
    466. System prevents drift and maintains quality
    47
    48**Pain Points Addressed**:
    49
    50- Current flat agent selection misses coordinated workflows
    51- No security boundaries on tool access
    52- Reactive rather than proactive quality assurance
    53- Inefficient model allocation increases costs
    54- Missing critical agents cause workflow gaps
    55
    56## Why
    57
    58- **Business Value**: Prevents security vulnerabilities and code quality issues before they reach production
    59- **Integration**: Extends existing Claude Code agent system with minimal breaking changes
    60- **Problems Solved**:
    61  - Eliminates manual agent coordination
    62  - Prevents tool access security vulnerabilities
    63  - Reduces technical debt through proactive quality hooks
    64  - Optimizes AI model costs through cognitive load matching
    65  - Fills critical workflow gaps with missing agents
    66
    67## What
    68
    69### User-Visible Behavior
    70
    71- Agents automatically coordinate in predefined chains for common workflows
    72- Security-sensitive operations require explicit confirmation
    73- Proactive quality suggestions appear before problems occur
    74- Model selection happens transparently based on task complexity
    75- Comprehensive validation occurs before code reaches production
    76
    77### Technical Requirements
    78
    79- Hierarchical orchestration layer above current agent system
    80- Role-based tool permission enforcement
    81- Soft hook system that integrates with existing Claude Code hooks
    82- Dynamic model allocation based on cognitive complexity
    83- Agent chain configuration and execution engine
    84
    85### Success Criteria
    86
    87- [ ] Primary orchestrator agents coordinate multi-agent workflows automatically
    88- [ ] Tool permissions enforced - read-only agents cannot use Write/Edit/Bash tools
    89- [ ] Soft hooks trigger proactive quality chains on code changes
    90- [ ] Model allocation matches cognitive complexity (haikusonnetopus)
    91- [ ] Missing agents (debugger, security-scanner, etc.) fill workflow gaps
    92- [ ] Agent chains execute reliably with fallback mechanisms
    93- [ ] Security boundaries prevent unauthorized tool access across agents
    94- [ ] Performance maintains sub-2-second agent selection times
    95- [ ] Cost optimization through appropriate model allocation
    96- [ ] Integration preserves existing agent functionality
    97
    98## All Needed Context

    12## Goal
    13
    14**Feature Goal**: Transform the Claude Code sub-agent system from flat agent delegation to hierarchical orchestration with autonomous agent selection, security-first tool allocation, and proactive quality assurance through soft hooks.
    15
    16**Deliverable**:
    17
    18- Hierarchical orchestration system with primary orchestrator agents
    19- Security-based tool allocation matrix with role-based permissions
    20- Missing critical agents (debugger, security-scanner, dependency-manager, pr-optimizer, context-engineer)
    21- Soft hook system for drift prevention
    22- Cognitive load-based model allocation strategy
    23- Agent orchestration chains for common workflows
    24
    25**Success Definition**:
    26
    27- Agents autonomously coordinate in chains (code-reviewer  security-scanner  test-automator)
    28- Tool permissions enforced by role (read-only agents cannot edit)
    29- Proactive quality hooks prevent issues before they occur
    30- Model allocation optimizes cost vs complexity
    31- One-pass implementation success through comprehensive context
    32

    34
    35**Target User**: Claude Code users working on complex software projects requiring multi-step workflows, security validation, and code quality assurance

    411. User makes code change
    422. Soft hook triggers proactive quality chain
    433. Hierarchical agents coordinate automatically
    444. Security boundaries enforced throughout
    455. User receives comprehensive feedback
    466. System prevents drift and maintains quality
    47

    49
    50- Current flat agent selection misses coordinated workflows
    51- No security boundaries on tool access
    52- Reactive rather than proactive quality assurance
    53- Inefficient model allocation increases costs
    54- Missing critical agents cause workflow gaps

   200### Known Gotchas of our Codebase & Library Quirks
   201
   202```python
   203# CRITICAL: Claude Code agent tool restrictions
   204# Agent tools field must be comma-separated strings, no brackets
   205# WRONG: tools: [Read, Write, Edit]
   206# WRONG: tools: ["Read", "Write", "Edit"]
   207# RIGHT: tools: Read, Write, Edit
   208
   209# CRITICAL: Hook system subprocess communication
   210# Hooks receive JSON via stdin, must output JSON to stdout
   211# All hook scripts must handle timeout gracefully (10 second limit)
   212# UV run required for dependency isolation
   213
   214# CRITICAL: Agent frontmatter schema
   215# name: kebab-case (no spaces, no underscores)
   216# description: Natural language for Claude's automatic delegation
   217# model: haiku, sonnet, or opus (exactly these strings)
   218# tools: Optional field - omit entirely for full access
   219
   220# CRITICAL: MCP tool inheritance
   221# Agents inherit MCP tools from main thread unless tools field specified
   222# Tool restrictions apply to both built-in and MCP tools
   223# Security implications for unrestricted MCP access
   224```

   378### Implementation Patterns & Key Details
   379
   380```python
   381# Agent frontmatter pattern - Tool security enforcement
   382---
   383name: security-scanner
   384description: Proactively scans code for OWASP top 10 vulnerabilities and security issues. Use immediately after code changes or before PR creation.
   385tools: Read, Grep, Bash, WebFetch  # NO Write/Edit - read-only security agent
   386model: opus  # Security analysis requires deep reasoning
   387---
   388
   389# Orchestration chain execution pattern
   390async def execute_agent_chain(chain_name: str, context: dict) -> dict:
   391    # PATTERN: Load chain configuration from YAML
   392    chain_config = load_chain_config(chain_name)
   393
   394    # CRITICAL: Validate agent tool permissions before execution
   395    for agent in chain_config.sequence:
   396        validate_agent_tools(agent, context.get('operation_type'))
   397
   398    # PATTERN: Sequential execution with context passing
   399    results = []
   400    for agent in chain_config.sequence:
   401        result = await execute_agent(agent, context)
   402        context.update(result)  # Context accumulation
   403        results.append(result)
   404
   405    return aggregate_results(results)
   406
   407# Tool permission enforcement pattern
   408def validate_tool_access(agent_name: str, tool_name: str) -> bool:
   409    # PATTERN: Load permission matrix from YAML config
   410    permissions = load_tool_permissions()
   411
   412    # CRITICAL: Explicit permission required, no implicit access
   413    agent_role = get_agent_role(agent_name)
   414    allowed_tools = permissions.get(agent_role, {}).get('tools', [])
   415
   416    # GOTCHA: Handle wildcard permissions carefully for security
   417    if '*' in allowed_tools:
   418        return requires_confirmation(agent_name, tool_name)
   419
   420    return tool_name in allowed_tools
   421
   422# Soft hook integration pattern
   423def register_soft_hook(hook_name: str, trigger_condition: callable):
   424    # PATTERN: Extend existing hook system without breaking changes
   425    # CRITICAL: Hooks can be overridden but must log warnings
   426    # INTEGRATION: Use existing hook subprocess communication protocol
   427    pass
   428```

## Goal

**Feature Goal**: Transform the Claude Code sub-agent system from flat agent delegation to hierarchical orchestration with autonomous agent selection, security-first tool allocation, and proactive quality assurance through soft hooks.

**Deliverable**:

- Hierarchical orchestration system with primary orchestrator agents
- Security-based tool allocation matrix with role-based permissions
- Missing critical agents (debugger, security-scanner, dependency-manager, pr-optimizer, context-engineer)
- Soft hook system for drift prevention
- Cognitive load-based model allocation strategy
- Agent orchestration chains for common workflows

**Success Definition**:

- Agents autonomously coordinate in chains (code-reviewer  security-scanner  test-automator)
- Tool permissions enforced by role (read-only agents cannot edit)
- Proactive quality hooks prevent issues before they occur
- Model allocation optimizes cost vs complexity
- One-pass implementation success through comprehensive context

## User Persona

**Target User**: Claude Code users working on complex software projects requiring multi-step workflows, security validation, and code quality assurance

**Use Case**: Developer writes code, system automatically triggers code-reviewer  security-scanner  test-automator chain, prevents insecure code from reaching production, and optimizes agent model usage based on task complexity

**User Journey**:

1. User makes code change
2. Soft hook triggers proactive quality chain
3. Hierarchical agents coordinate automatically
4. Security boundaries enforced throughout
5. User receives comprehensive feedback
6. System prevents drift and maintains quality

**Pain Points Addressed**:

- Current flat agent selection misses coordinated workflows
- No security boundaries on tool access
- Reactive rather than proactive quality assurance
- Inefficient model allocation increases costs
- Missing critical agents cause workflow gaps

## Why

- **Business Value**: Prevents security vulnerabilities and code quality issues before they reach production
- **Integration**: Extends existing Claude Code agent system with minimal breaking changes
- **Problems Solved**:
  - Eliminates manual agent coordination
  - Prevents tool access security vulnerabilities
  - Reduces technical debt through proactive quality hooks
  - Optimizes AI model costs through cognitive load matching
  - Fills critical workflow gaps with missing agents

## What

### User-Visible Behavior

- Agents automatically coordinate in predefined chains for common workflows
- Security-sensitive operations require explicit confirmation
- Proactive quality suggestions appear before problems occur
- Model selection happens transparently based on task complexity
- Comprehensive validation occurs before code reaches production

### Technical Requirements

- Hierarchical orchestration layer above current agent system
- Role-based tool permission enforcement
- Soft hook system that integrates with existing Claude Code hooks
- Dynamic model allocation based on cognitive complexity
- Agent chain configuration and execution engine

### Success Criteria

- [ ] Primary orchestrator agents coordinate multi-agent workflows automatically
- [ ] Tool permissions enforced - read-only agents cannot use Write/Edit/Bash tools
- [ ] Soft hooks trigger proactive quality chains on code changes
- [ ] Model allocation matches cognitive complexity (haikusonnetopus)
- [ ] Missing agents (debugger, security-scanner, etc.) fill workflow gaps
- [ ] Agent chains execute reliably with fallback mechanisms
- [ ] Security boundaries prevent unauthorized tool access across agents
- [ ] Performance maintains sub-2-second agent selection times
- [ ] Cost optimization through appropriate model allocation
- [ ] Integration preserves existing agent functionality

### Known Gotchas of our Codebase & Library Quirks

```python
# CRITICAL: Claude Code agent tool restrictions
# Agent tools field must be comma-separated strings, no brackets
# WRONG: tools: [Read, Write, Edit]
# WRONG: tools: ["Read", "Write", "Edit"]
# RIGHT: tools: Read, Write, Edit

# CRITICAL: Hook system subprocess communication
# Hooks receive JSON via stdin, must output JSON to stdout
# All hook scripts must handle timeout gracefully (10 second limit)
# UV run required for dependency isolation

# CRITICAL: Agent frontmatter schema
# name: kebab-case (no spaces, no underscores)
# description: Natural language for Claude's automatic delegation
# model: haiku, sonnet, or opus (exactly these strings)
# tools: Optional field - omit entirely for full access

# CRITICAL: MCP tool inheritance
# Agents inherit MCP tools from main thread unless tools field specified
# Tool restrictions apply to both built-in and MCP tools
# Security implications for unrestricted MCP access
```

## Implementation Blueprint

### Data Models and Structure

Create the core configuration models for orchestration system:

```yaml
# .claude/config/agent-orchestration.yaml - Chain definitions
orchestration:
  chains:
    code_quality:
      trigger: "code_change"
      sequence: ["code-reviewer", "security-scanner", "test-automator"]
      fallback: ["manual-review"]

    feature_development:
      trigger: "feature_request"
      sequence: ["technical-researcher", "workflow-orchestrator", "implementer"]
      parallel: ["test-automator", "smart-doc-generator"]

    bug_fix:
      trigger: "error_detected"
      sequence: ["debugger", "root-cause-analyzer", "fix-implementer"]
      validation: ["regression-tester"]

# .claude/config/tool-permissions.yaml - Security boundaries
permissions:
  read_only:
    tools: [Read, Grep, Glob, WebFetch, mcp__Ref]
    agents: [code-reviewer, security-scanner, technical-researcher]

  write_limited:
    tools: [Read, Write, Edit]
    patterns: ["*.md", "test/**/*", "docs/**/*"]
    agents: [smart-doc-generator, test-automator]

  execution_restricted:
    tools: [Read, Bash, Grep]
    commands: ["git status", "npm test", "pytest", "security-scan"]
    agents: [debugger, dependency-manager]

  full_access:
    tools: ["*"]
    confirmation_required: true
    agents: [meta-agent, workflow-orchestrator]

# .claude/config/model-allocation.yaml - Cognitive complexity mapping
models:
  haiku:
    complexity: "simple"
    tasks: ["formatting", "validation", "status_checks"]
    cost_factor: 1

  sonnet:
    complexity: "moderate"
    tasks: ["analysis", "debugging", "code_review", "testing"]
    cost_factor: 3

  opus:
    complexity: "high"
    tasks: ["orchestration", "architecture", "security", "meta_reasoning"]
    cost_factor: 15
```
